Movie: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot

Review: The movie is worth seeing for the story it tells, which is too often neglected when we speak of migrants coming to Europe. It also has a very solid performance by the lead. However, I was really disappointed at how safe it was, sensationalising the migrant journey, and never thought provoking. It felt like a movie addressing us Europeans, trying to please our vision of Africa as a dangerous place, without ever bringing up our responsibility in this tragic situation.â€¦

There have been so many love letters to cinema recently, to the point that I got sick of it... but Victor Erice did it like none other. He understood that cinema goes beyond entertainment: it has the power to dictate your life. Only after you see Cerrar Los Ojos will you understand why some people consider going to the movies a religious experience. After a 30 years long hiatus, the Spanish master certainly did not disappoint. Â¡Maravilloso!

Movie: Maxine's Baby: The Tyler Perry Story

Review: I found Scorsese's distancing style particularly well suited to tell the story of traumatic historical events without risking being insensitive, as is often the case with Hollywood's sensationalist approach. We never really emotionally empathise with the characters, nor do we experience suspense. Instead, we scrutinise and judge the facts presented on screen, without ever feeling led by the hand or manipulated. The acknowledgement of his own limits as a white filmmaker by taking the perspective of a white catholic protagonistâ€¦

Writing at 5AM because I just woke up from a nightmare in which I had to see this again
TÃ¡r + Decision to Leave = French court drama

Getting punched so hard in the face at 9AM was not what I was expecting, but what I needed. People getting out of the movie theater afterwards resembled a funeral, yet the film never showed death. Any work that makes me lose faith in humanity is a masterpiece.
